The music of Richie Havens, who died yesterday at the age of 72.
Tomorrow, Neal Conan will be back for a conversation about the challenges facing survivors after tragedies.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Jennifer Ludden in Washington.
For the first time in nearly 60 years, Americans whose property was seized after the Cuban revolution can sue for restitution.
And these Americans aren't going after the Cuban government; they're going after foreign companies they say are profiting off their confiscated assets.
As NPR's Carrie Kahn reports, the first suit, against Carnival Cruise Lines, was filed this week.
Buses pull up to the door of the recently refurbished cruise ship terminal on the edge of Havana Harbor.
Dozens of sunburned, tired tourists step off.
Back to the ship, jump in the pool, cool off.
Ellen Haggerty says the cruise has been great and touring Havana wonderful.
Because the people are nice.
They're sweet.
Cuba's government has been restoring a lot of Havana with dollars from tourists like Haggerty, but if President Trump has his way, that foreign investment will dry up.
He's allowed provisions under the Helms-Burton law to go forward; the first U.S.
president to do so since it was passed back in 1996.
Americans can now sue foreign companies using property they say was theirs and confiscated by the Cuban government back in the 1960s.
Also, he's curbing tourist travel to Cuba.
Tourist Haggerty says she doesn't care what Trump thinks.
Well, that's his problem.
It's my money; I'll spend it where I want to spend it.
But for Mickael Behn, Trump's sanctions are long overdue.
Reached by phone in Miami, Behn says those docks where the cruise ships land belong to his family.
His family ran the Havana Docks Company from 1917 until November 21, 1960; that's the day two armed men barged into the company's offices and confronted his grandfather.
It's fragile, but it's still holding.
There has been isolated rocket fire from Gaza into Israel since the ceasefire was announced.
Israel has not responded to that rocket fire.
And Olmert had said he want to give the ceasefire a chance to work.
Secretary Rice said that she would like to see the ceasefire extended to the West Bank.
Abbas said that's something he would like to see as well.
So that's also going to be on the agenda with Olmert, whether or not they can extend the ceasefire as a first step to renewing peace negotiations.
One of the issues causing friction between Israel and the Palestinians is an Israeli soldier still missing after being captured last summer.
There has been talk for months of a prisoner swap.
What's the latest on that?
The negotiations are going on and there are sort of conflicting reports, with some reports saying they're very close to an agreement and some saying they're still very far away.
The deal would be that this soldier, Gilad Shalit, would be freed in exchange for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.
Hamas originally demanded 1400; Israel offered 400.
So now they're sort of negotiating in the middle.
It's also a question of exactly who will be released.

One if the things that Olmert said in his speech is that it will be Palestinians serving long-term, which means that it will be Palestinians who had been involved in killing Israelis; that's also something new.
Until now, Israel has refused to release them.
But it does not seem that this is imminent at all.
There's still negotiations going on.
There are, by the way, two other Israeli soldiers who were captured on the northern border by Hezbollah soldiers this summer.
The Red Cross this week said they still have not received any signs of life from those two soldiers.
But Gilad Shalit, the soldier in Gaza, is still believed to be alive.
NPR's Linda Gradstein, speaking from Jerusalem.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Now to the woman who preceded Hillary Clinton as America's top diplomat.
Condoleezza Rice has returned to Stanford University after a 10-year absence.
The former secretary of state is taking up the relatively quiet life of a scholar at the Hoover Institution think tank.
KQED's Scott Shafer visited Stanford to see what kind of reception she's getting.
When Condoleezza Rice left Stanford a decade ago, she was running the place.
She was the youngest provost in the university's history.
And she steered the institution through a fiscal crisis with painful spending cuts.
That episode may seem almost quaint to her now after two controversial terms in the Bush administration.
Eight years is a very long time.
And we had eight very consequential, tumultuous years.
And it was definitely time to go.
It's nice to get up and read the newspaper and not think you have to do anything about what's in it.
Few, if any, of the students walking, skateboarding and biking around campus these days were even here when Rice left to work for then-Governor George W.
Bush.
That doesn't mean people are indifferent about her return.
Outside a university food court, campus pastor Lindsay Holly recalled some of the more controversial issues of the Bush presidency and Rice's role in them.
I think some of the decisions that she made particularly concerning the way people were treated in Guantanamo Bay could even be considered war crimes.
And there hasn't really been any, I guess, public call for her to take responsibility for those things.
Like much of California, Stanford leans to the left, politically.
In fact, voters in the precinct located on campus favored Barack Obama over John McCain by more than seven to one.
But after living in the cauldron of Washington politics, the world of ideas and critical thinking may seem like a respite to Rice.
This is a university.
If you can't have a good debate or good argument in a university, where can you have a good debate or a good argument?
Look, they were controversial decisions and they were tough decisions.
Rice is joining another former secretary of state here: George Shultz, who served under President Reagan.
I'm delighted to have her back.
I've missed her.
Shultz is now 88 years old and he predicts Rice's presence here will stimulate lively discussion.
She'll be challenged, but so will they be challenged because sometimes you know more than they do, if you have been in the heat of it.
Secretary Rice says she's ready for a spirited debate within limits.
I don't believe in confrontation.
That seems to me outside civil discourse and we all have to find way to be civil to one another.
That may take some restraint from Stanford History Professor Barton Bernstein.
An outspoken critic of the Iraq war, Bernstein says he has contempt for some Bush administration policies that Condoleezza Rice helped implement.

I feel it incumbent upon me morally, to indicate my great dismay and thorough disapproval of the administration in foreign policy and what we believe to be her important role in those crucial decisions.
And yet, by and large, there is a civility, even enthusiasm for Rice's return in places you might not expect - like among the Stanford Democrats political organization.
Club president Ashwin Mudaliar and the group's political director Elizabeth D'Aunno are both eager to have Secretary Rice back on campus with conditions.
Well, I certainly don't think we should be greeting her with flowers and chocolate.
But, at the same time, I don't think protest is completely necessary.
Professor Rice has done a lot for this university and we should give her due respect for that.

Well, I think we should greet her with a big old invitation, signed by every student on campus, to have a three-night speaker series where she can talk about her role, specifically, in the Iraq war, her experience, more generally, in the administration and perhaps what she feels like she gained from that experience that will help her to be even better moving forward.
Rice won't be teaching right away, but she plans to hold seminars and after-dinner talks in student dorms and write several books.

In the meantime, Condoleezza Rice is likely to be seen on campus at Stanford basketball games, or maybe playing a round of golf with her old friend, George Shultz, as she replaces the pressure cooker of international diplomacy with leisurely reflection on the very turbulent eight years of the Bush administration.
For NPR News, I'm Scott Shafer in San Francisco.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
